posts.name: Team 4738
posts.cooked:
Disclaimer: We found a solution to the bending keys (superglue) but we have no idea how good of a fix this is. If you have the same problem, try this fix at your own risk, I don’t know if/how long it will last

Story: Our team recently got the new MAXSwerve from REV Robotics after waiting since November last year. We were so excited to get these modules that we stopped eating dinner just to start working on them. As an aside, I’d just like to say that other than the problems with the keys, the quality of the modules was immaculate; we were all blown away. After figuring out our own issues we finally were able to produce 4 “functioning” swerve modules. All 4 had normal smooth motion just as REV specified. Our next step was to test out the functionality, so we handed them off to our programing team. After some testing of the modules outside the frame, they started complaining of binding in the drive wheel and plastic shavings falling out as they ran them. Very concerned, we took both modules that were being tested and completely disassembled them finding these stuck between our NEO shaft and encoder bridge.

IMG_6228 1920×2560 208 KB IMG_6226 1920×2560 181 KB 20230115_123324 3000×4000 230 KB

IMG_6228 1920×2560 208 KB

IMG_6228 1920×2560 208 KB

IMG_6226 1920×2560 181 KB

IMG_6226 1920×2560 181 KB

20230115_123324 3000×4000 230 KB

20230115_123324 3000×4000 230 KB

And I think it goes without saying, but that’s probably not supposed to happen. We eventually came to the conclusion that somehow the key was sliding out of the key way, wedging itself between the bridge and shaft, then proceeding to be bent around the shaft of the NEO. This is what caused the binding as well as the plastic everywhere. After some more testing of the fit between the key and the keyway, we realized that not only was the key looser than a regular CIM style key but also that the key was loose enough, with the pinion inserted, to fully slide out of the keyway and into the encoder bridge. And I’d also like to stress that we had quite a few team members check over the instructions on orientation of the keyway and clearance with the encoder bridge so I don’t think this was an error on our part but if it is, I’d love to know what we did wrong.

After learning that looseness was the issue, we assumed that the best option to fix the key into place was superglue. Just a couple of dabs worth in the keyway was enough to solve the binding and grinding completely on all the modules and we ran them in the frame without a snag for over 30 mins. Now, like I said at the start, I’m not to sure how permanent CA glue will be in the long run especially in a high load environment like a gearbox so take this advice with a grain of salt for now. I just wanted to post this here in case anyone else has had this issue and needed a quick fix or if anyone has a suggestion on a more long term solution. Thank you in advance to anyone who can help

posts.name: Harrison Drake
posts.cooked:
I’m assuming this is the failure mode that manifests when the key and encoder fork do not clear each other as pointed out in step 4. Failure to make sure this is happening means the NEO and NEO 550 are directly fighting each other.

image 771×720 73.8 KB

image 771×720 73.8 KB

image 771×720 73.8 KB

Spinning the encoder fork by hand should NOT spin the Neo output shaft. If they do, the key needs to be slid further towards the end of the NEO keyway.

posts.name: Team 4738
posts.cooked: Right, when these were first assembled, we checked the clearance between the notch in the key and the encoder bridge and there was plenty of clearance. We were able to freely spin the pinion independently from the encoder bridge. After assembly, both the wheel and azimuth also spun freely and independently from each other, it was only once the wheel was run at high speeds that we started to see binding of the wheel.

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked:
HDrake:

Spinning the encoder fork by hand should NOT spin the Neo output shaft. If they do, the key needs to be slid further towards the end of the NEO keyway.

We’ve run out of space on the keyway – pulled the key as far to the end as it will go, and the notch on the key doesn’t clear the lip.

posts.name: Jack
posts.cooked:
We’ve run into a similar issue on assembly on one of our spare modules, it appears the key is loose and slips down the shaft into it. (This is made worse when the module is ran by hand upside down due to gravity)

One potential cause we see to double check is the motor pinion orientation, as if the “flange” is pointing down it will apply more pressure to the key to slip into the wrong slot.

Please let us know if you’ve found the issue!

posts.name: Jack
posts.cooked:
Update:

Think we’ve narrowed down the issue.

We used a NEO 1.1 on our original modules, and a 1.0 on the one with the issue. The key way is significantly longer (maybe just more inconsistent?) on the 1.0, causing the drop into the encoder bridge.

Edit: REV instructed us to resolve this by just superglueing the key flush with the top. Seems to work just fine.

image 1920×1440 124 KB

image 1920×1440 124 KB

image 1920×1440 124 KB

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: That’s a great catch!  We used all 1.0 NEOs for ours.  We haven’t seen this issue YET but I can definitely see that it could happen, and so I think taking modules apart & gluing the keys in may be in order…

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked: NEO 1.0 Keyways seem to be somewhat inconsistent – it sits lower on some shafts than on others – we’ve found variations of up to 3/4 mm.  And, unfortunately, that’s enough to push the key from clearing the encoder bridge to not clearing it.

posts.name: Emile Hamwey
posts.cooked: Thanks for sharing this - we’re building our MAXSwerve this weekend and will be taking note.

posts.name: Charlie Peskay
posts.cooked:
Had the same issue-seems to have caused slight damage to the encoder bridge, but everything else seems fine. We think the module might have been assembled wrong, with the lip on the motor pinion the wrong way, as it makes sense for that to be the cause. This was with a Neo V1.1. image 1920×1440 154 KB

image 1920×1440 154 KB

image 1920×1440 154 KB

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: We superglued our keys in today.  I can attest that once a key is glued in it will NOT come out again.  We have one NEO with a key glued slightly too low.  We tried acetone overnight and it would not budge, eventually we filed down one spot so it would clear the encoder bridge.

posts.name: Benjamin Broudy
posts.cooked: Ours are still holding up woth lots of drive testing, sounds like theyll be pretty stuck in there for a while with what youve said lol
